John Willard Milnor ( 1931 ) is an American mathematician known for his work in differential topology, algebraic K-theory and low-dimensional holomorphic dynamical systems. Milnor is a distinguished professor at Stony Brook University and the only mathematician to have won the Fields Medal, the Wolf Prize, the Abel Prize and all three Steele prizes. Here are some of his most notable scientific contributions: 1. Differential Topology: Milnor's work in differential topology, particularly his discovery of exotic spheres (smooth 7-dimensional spheres that are not diffeomorphic to the standard 7-dimensional sphere), was groundbreaking. This work, for which he was awarded the Fields Medal in 1962, played a key role in the development of differential topology. 2. Morse Theory: Milnor's book "Morse Theory" became a fundamental text in the field. Morse theory relates the topology of a manifold to the critical points of a smooth function on the manifold. His clear exposition and insightful treatment of the subject have made this theory more accessible and applicable to a broader range of mathematical disciplines. 3. Singular Points of Complex Hypersurfaces: In this area, Milnor studied the singular points of complex hypersurfaces, which led to the development of what is now known as Milnor fibration. His work on singularities has been influential in both algebraic geometry and topology. 4. H-Cobordism Theorem: Milnor's proof of the h-cobordism theorem was another major contribution to differential topology. This theorem, which gives conditions under which a cobordism is trivial, has been a foundational result in the classification of high-dimensional manifolds. 5. K-Theory and Algebraic Topology: Milnor also made significant contributions to algebraic K-theory and algebraic topology. His work in these areas has influenced a wide range of mathematical research, including the study of vector bundles and the formulation of new homotopy groups. 6. Dynamical Systems: In the field of dynamical systems, Milnor's work focused on the study of iterated polynomials and complex dynamics. His insights have been influential in understanding the behavior of dynamical systems and chaos theory. Throughout his career, Milnor has been recognized for his ability to clarify and simplify complex mathematical ideas, making them accessible to a broader audience. His contributions have had a lasting impact on the field of mathematics, influencing both theoretical research and practical applications. https://lnkd.in/dDM7AeB8 Sources: Wikipedia, Stony Brook and AI tools have been used to edit. Jean-Pierre Serre ( 1926 ) is a French mathematician who has made contributions to algebraic topology, algebraic geometry and algebraic number theory. He was awarded the Fields Medal in 1954, the Wolf Prize in 2000 and the inaugural Abel Prize in 2003. Some of his most notable scientific contributions include: 1. Serre's Conjecture (later Faltings' Theorem): He formulated a conjecture in algebraic number theory, which was later proved by Gerd Faltings. This conjecture relates Galois representations of algebraic number fields to modular forms. 2. Serre's Theorem on Projective Modules: In algebra, Serre's theorem states that finitely generated projective modules over a polynomial ring are free. This was a key result in commutative algebra and algebraic K-theory. 3. Serre's Criterion for Affineness: In algebraic geometry, he provided a criterion that characterizes affine varieties in terms of their cohomology. 4. Serre's Modularity Conjecture: He conjectured a deep connection between Galois representations and modular forms. This conjecture has profound implications in number theory and was a key motivation for the development of the Langlands program. 5. Serre Duality: This is a fundamental theorem in algebraic geometry that relates the cohomology groups of a coherent sheaf on a projective variety with the dual of another cohomology group. 6. Serre's Multiplicity Conjectures: These conjectures in commutative algebra relate multiplicities of certain modules associated with local rings to their Hilbert series. 7. Contributions to Group Cohomology: He extensively studied the cohomology of groups, significantly advancing the understanding in this area. 8. Serre–Tate Theory: Along with John Tate, he developed a theory about good reduction of abelian varieties. 9. Serre's C*-algebra: In the theory of operator algebras, he introduced the concept of C*-algebras in a group-theoretic context. 10. GAGA Principles: He formulated principles relating algebraic geometry over complex numbers with analytic geometry. 11. Serre's Theorem on Homotopy Groups of Spheres: One of Serre's famous results is a theorem concerning the homotopy groups of spheres. This theorem provides information about the torsion in these groups, revealing deep and intricate structures within them. His work shed light on the previously unknown properties of higher-dimensional spheres. Jean-Pierre Serre's work has been highly influential in modern mathematics, contributing to the development of several key theories and concepts in various branches of mathematics. His work continues to inspire and inform current research in these fields. Pierre René, Viscount Deligne ( 1944 ) is a Belgian mathematician. He is best known for work on the Weil conjectures, leading to a complete proof in 1973. Has made significant contributions to several areas of mathematics, especially in algebraic geometry and number theory. He is the winner of the 2013 Abel Prize, 2008 Wolf Prize, 1988 Crafoord Prize, and 1978 Fields Medal. From 1970 until 1984, Deligne was a permanent member of the IHÉS staff. In 1984, Deligne moved to the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton. His most notable achievements include: 1. Proof of the Weil Conjectures: Deligne's work on the Weil conjectures is perhaps his most celebrated contribution. These conjectures, proposed by André Weil, relate the number of solutions of equations over finite fields to the topology of the equations' complex solutions. Deligne's proof of the last and deepest of these conjectures, the "Weil conjecture on Tamagawa numbers," earned him the Fields Medal in 1978. 2. Deligne Cohomology: In algebraic geometry, Deligne developed a theory of mixed Hodge structures and introduced what is now known as Deligne cohomology. This work has had a profound impact on the field, providing deep insights into the nature of algebraic varieties. 3. Work on Hodge Theory and Singularities: Deligne made significant contributions to Hodge theory, which is a central tool in modern algebraic geometry. His work helped in understanding the role of singularities in various contexts, which has applications in many areas of mathematics. 4. Contributions to the Langlands Program: He has also made important contributions to the Langlands program, a set of deep conjectures connecting number theory and representation theory. 5. Tannakian Categories: Deligne's work on Tannakian categories has been influential in representation theory and algebraic geometry. This concept provides a framework for understanding linear algebraic groups and their representations. 6. Kazhdan–Lusztig Conjectures: Deligne, along with David Kazhdan and George Lusztig, worked on the Kazhdan–Lusztig conjectures, which have deep implications in representation theory and algebraic geometry. 7. Moduli Spaces and Stacks: He has done significant work in the study of moduli spaces and stacks, which are important in the study of algebraic surfaces and other geometric structures. Deligne's work, characterized by deep insight and technical mastery, has had a wide-ranging impact across mathematics, influencing both the development of new theories and the solution of long-standing problems. https://lnkd.in/daEpuZGF Sources: Wiki, Yves Laszlo, Raphael Douady, IAS, IAs and Humans AIFI - Artificial Intelligence Finance Institute

Tropical algebra: Consider the set of real numbers and the two operations of "tropical addition" x ta y = min(x, y) and "tropical multiplication" x tm y = x + y. An alternative form of tropical algebra uses max(x, y) for addition. Computations of tropical algebra are easier/faster to implement in hardware, because multiplication is simplified to addition and exponentiation to multiplication. When real-valued input data is encoded as the transition instant of a signal from 0 to 1, a single OR gate can perform tropical addition. The descriptor "tropical" was attached to this algebra by French mathematicians in honor of the Hungarian-born Brazilian computer scientist Imre Simon, who published several papers on these ideas in the late 1970s. Apparently, to Frenchmen, Brazil is quite tropical! Some on-line sources credit Bernard Carre's 1971 paper, "An Algebra for Network Routing Problems," as the birthplace of these ideas. Many of the properties of ordinary algebra are valid in tropical algebra. For example, distributivity holds: x tm (y ta z) = (x tm y) ta (x tm z) Translation: x + min(y, z) = min(x + y, x + z) A polynomial in tropical algebra takes the form: f(x) = (a(0)) ta (a(1) tm x) ta (a(2) tm 2x) ta . . . ta (a(n) tm nx) = min(a(0), a(1) + x, a(2) + 2x, . . . , a(n) + nx) Explanation for tropical exponentiation: x te j = jx Tropical algebra began garnering serious attention when it was realized that the Floyd-Warshall shortest-path algorithm using min-plus operations can be formulated in tropical algebra. There is more to tropical math than the short introduction above. For example, there is tropical geometry, tropical analysis, and tropical cryptography, to name a few related areas. The following book describes Tropical geometry as "a combinatorial shadow of algebraic geometry, offering new polyhedral tools to compute invariants of algebraic varieties. It is based on tropical algebra, where the sum of two numbers is their minimum and the product is their sum. This turns polynomials into piecewise-linear functions, and their zero sets into polyhedral complexes. These tropical varieties retain a surprising amount of information about their classical counterparts." Maclagan, Diane and Bernd Sturmfels, 'Introduction to Tropical Geometry,' American Mathematical Society, 2015. Here is a nice introduction to tropical mathematics: https://lnkd.in/gMmwcQrV

Vladimir Igorevich Arnold ( 1937 – 2010 ) was a Russian mathematician. He is known for the Kolmogorov–Arnold–Moser theorem regarding the stability of integrable systems, and contributed to several areas, including geometrical theory of dynamical systems theory, algebra, catastrophe theory, topology, algebraic geometry, symplectic geometry, symplectic topology, differential equations, classical mechanics, differential geometric approach to hydrodynamics, geometric analysis and singularity theory, including posing the ADE classification problem. Here are some of his key contributions: 1. KAM Theory: Together with Andrei Kolmogorov and Jürgen Moser, Arnold developed the Kolmogorov-Arnold-Moser (KAM) theory. This theory addresses the stability of integrable systems in classical mechanics and provides conditions under which an integrable Hamiltonian system can be slightly perturbed without becoming chaotic, thus explaining the persistence of quasi-periodic motions in certain systems. 2. Arnold Diffusion: In celestial mechanics, Arnold contributed to the understanding of the diffusion process in the phase space of Hamiltonian systems, which can lead to slow changes in the orbit of a celestial body over a long time. 3. Singularity Theory: Arnold made significant advancements in singularity theory, which studies the properties of spaces that are not smooth, like the points of a cone or the edge of a cube. His work laid the foundation for understanding the classification and characterization of singularities in different contexts. 4. Arnold's Conjecture in Symplectic Geometry: This conjecture relates fixed points of a Hamiltonian symplectomorphism to the topology of the underlying manifold. It has been a central problem in symplectic geometry and has driven much research in the field. 5. Topological Fluid Dynamics: Arnold applied topological methods to the study of fluid dynamics, offering a new perspective on the behavior of incompressible flows. This approach led to what is now known as Arnold's structure theorem, which describes the global structure of steady flows. 6. Arnold's Cat Map: In the field of dynamical systems, Arnold introduced the concept of the cat map, a linear, chaotic map that is an example of an Anosov diffeomorphism. This concept is used in various fields, including cryptography and image processing. 7. Ergodic Theory: Arnold also made contributions to ergodic theory, which deals with the statistical properties of dynamical systems. 8. Mathematical Education: Beyond his direct research contributions, Arnold was known for his unique approach to teaching. His textbooks and problems have influenced mathematical education worldwide. Arnold's work is characterized by its depth, originality, and the elegant application of geometric and topological methods to solve complex problems in various fields of mathematics and physics. Sun-Yung Alice Chang (Chinese: 張聖容 ) (1948) is a Taiwanese American mathematician specializing in aspects of mathematical analysis ranging from harmonic analysis and partial differential equations to differential geometry. She is the Eugene Higgins Professor of Mathematics at Princeton University. Here are some key highlights of her scientific contributions: 1. Conformal Geometry: Chang has made significant contributions to conformal geometry, an area of mathematics focusing on properties that remain unchanged under conformal mappings. Her work in this field has helped deepen the understanding of how geometric structures behave under these transformations. 2. Geometric Inequalities: She has worked extensively on geometric inequalities, which are fundamental in understanding the relationships between different geometric quantities such as volume, area, and length in various geometric contexts. Her research has led to advancements in the comprehension of these inequalities in curved spaces. 3. Yamabe Problem: Chang has made notable contributions to the Yamabe problem, a famous problem in differential geometry concerning the existence of a metric with constant scalar curvature in a given conformal class on a compact manifold. Her work in this area has been influential in advancing both the theoretical understanding and practical applications of this problem. 4. Harmonic Analysis on Non-Compact Symmetric Spaces: Her research also extends to harmonic analysis, particularly on non-compact symmetric spaces. This work involves studying functions and their transformations and has applications in many areas of mathematics and theoretical physics. 5. Einstein Metrics and the Ricci Flow: Chang's work has contributed to the study of Einstein metrics and the Ricci flow, important concepts in differential geometry and general relativity. Her research in this area helps in understanding the geometric and topological properties of manifolds. 6. Analysis of Partial Differential Equations: She has also made significant contributions to the analysis of partial differential equations, which are fundamental in expressing a wide range of physical phenomena. Her work has implications in understanding complex systems in mathematical physics. 7. Mentorship and Leadership in Mathematics: Beyond her research, Chang has been a mentor and leader in the mathematical community. She has served in various significant roles, including as the President of the Association for Women in Mathematics, promoting diversity and inclusion in the field. Sun-Yung Alice Chang's work is characterized by its depth and its impact on both pure and applied mathematics. Her contributions have not only advanced theoretical knowledge but have also had practical implications in understanding the complex geometrical and analytical structures of the natural world. https://lnkd.in/dBbXQiWu AIFI - Artificial Intelligence Finance Institute

David Bryant Mumford (1937) is an American mathematician known for his work in algebraic geometry and then for research into vision and pattern theory. He won the Fields Medal and was a MacArthur Fellow. In 2010 he was awarded the National Medal of Science. He is currently a University Professor Emeritus of Applied Mathematics at Brown University. Here are some of his key scientific contributions: 1. Algebraic Geometry Mumford's work in algebraic geometry has had a lasting impact, with notable contributions in the following areas: - Geometric Invariant Theory (GIT): In his book "Geometric Invariant Theory" (first published in 1965), Mumford explored the role of group actions on algebraic varieties and developed the framework for understanding stability and moduli spaces. This work is crucial for understanding geometric structures that remain invariant under group transformations. - Moduli Spaces: Mumford worked extensively on moduli spaces, particularly in the context of algebraic curves and surfaces. His insights into the structure and classification of these spaces have influenced further research in algebraic geometry. - The Red Book of Varieties and Schemes: This book, based on lecture notes, provided an introduction to Grothendieck's scheme theory. It has served as an accessible resource for students and researchers interested in algebraic geometry. 2. Abelian Varieties Mumford's book "Abelian Varieties" (1970) is a classic text in algebraic geometry, offering a comprehensive treatment of abelian varieties. The book explores the theory of these algebraic groups and their applications in various areas of mathematics, such as number theory and complex geometry. 3. Pattern Theory and Computer Vision Later in his career, Mumford turned his attention to pattern theory and computer vision, where he made significant contributions: - Pattern Theory: Mumford's work in pattern theory involved mathematical frameworks for understanding complex patterns in visual data. He explored topics such as shape representation, image segmentation, and statistical models for visual perception. - Computer Vision: Mumford's research in computer vision focused on developing mathematical tools for analyzing and interpreting visual information. His work on Bayesian approaches to image segmentation and shape analysis has influenced the field. 4. Recognition and Awards Mumford's contributions have been widely recognized. He received the Fields Medal in 1974 for his work in algebraic geometry, particularly in moduli spaces and geometric invariant theory. He has also been awarded the Wolf Prize in Mathematics and has been a member of prestigious scientific academies. Overall, David Mumford's scientific contributions span multiple areas of mathematics, from algebraic geometry to pattern theory and computer vision. Robert Phelan Langlands, ( 1936 ) is a Canadian mathematician. He is best known as the founder of the Langlands program, a vast web of conjectures and results connecting representation theory and automorphic forms to the study of Galois groups in number theory,for which he received the 2018 Abel Prize. He also got the Wolf Prize in 1995. He was an emeritus professor and occupied Albert Einstein's office at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, until 2020 when he retired. Here are some key aspects of his scientific contributions: 1. Langlands Program: Langlands' most significant contribution is the formulation of the Langlands program. This set of conjectures and ideas, first proposed in a letter to André Weil in 1967, seeks to create a grand unifying theory linking areas of number theory, representation theory, and algebraic geometry. The program suggests deep connections between Galois groups (which arise in the study of polynomial equations and their roots) and automorphic forms (complex-valued functions with certain invariance properties). 2. Reciprocity Conjectures: A cornerstone of the Langlands program is the series of reciprocity conjectures. These conjectures generalize class field theory (which describes abelian extensions of number fields) to non-abelian Galois groups, proposing a correspondence between Galois representations and automorphic representations. This was a revolutionary idea that opened up new ways of thinking about and studying these mathematical objects. 3. Functoriality and Endoscopy: Langlands introduced the concept of functoriality within his program, which deals with how automorphic representations of one group relate to those of another group. He also developed the theory of endoscopy, a set of techniques to understand the internal structure of automorphic representations, particularly in cases where functorial transfer is not straightforward. 4. Trace Formula: Langlands made significant contributions to the development of the trace formula, a powerful tool in the study of automorphic forms. The trace formula is an analytic tool that allows mathematicians to count automorphic representations with certain properties. 5. Influence on Other Fields: The Langlands program has influenced various other areas of mathematics. It has played a role in the proof of major theorems, such as the proof of Fermat's Last Theorem by Andrew Wiles, and has been instrumental in the development of the theory of Shimura varieties in algebraic geometry. 6. Collaborations and Mentoring: Beyond his own research, Langlands has been influential through collaborations and mentoring other mathematicians, contributing to the growth and development of the field. His contributions have not only opened new avenues of research but have also provided a framework that connects various seemingly disparate areas of mathematics. https://lnkd.in/d7BYmRP4 AIFI - Artificial Intelligence Finance Institute
